results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This films shows the 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games, including the opening ceremony, athletes competing in events, decorations in the city and the arrival of Prince Philip to close the Olympic Games.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:51:00 Olympic sign featuring torch, ‘1956’ and the rings
00:08:27:00 cyclists on a velodrome
00:09:57:00 some spectacular diving at the Olympic Swimming Stadium
00:11:44:00 torch bearers running with the Olympic torch
00:13:45:00 the Opening Ceremony
00:20:10:00 Ron Clarke running into the stadium
00:21:00:00 Clarke lighting the cauldron
00:25:35:00 television broadcast vans including the Herald Sun, the ABC and GTV9
00:25:49:00 various track and field events
00:33:30:00 athletes walking up through the crowd of spectators
00:35:41:00 newspaper headlines for Betty Cuthbert’s win
00:41:47:00 Flinders Street Station decorated with the Olympic rings and flags
00:49:00:00 licence plate with Olympic rings
00:49:48:00 on the harbour for yachting
00:51:50:00 the arrival of Prince Philip
00:54:30:00 crowds, including people in costume
00:54:50:00 rows of parked 1950s cars
01:00:52:00 athletes sign autographs
01:02:01:00 a fallen cyclist is helped up by two officials
01:04:07:00 country flags lining a boulevard
01:11:12:00 a brass band
01:16:00:00 Olympic rings lit up at night
01:16:35:00 the closing ceremony

results.title: The Australian airman: 1939-1945
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “War Experience”.
The men who served in the Royal Australian Air Force during the Second World War. At first it was a European war - over Germany, France, and Italy, but then the allies were driven back over North Africa. The Japanese aggression brought the men back to Australian shores and Pacific islands. Joining the Air Force with a spirit of adventure, the close of the war saw broken spirits and mental and physical suffering.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 34]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film begins with scenes of kids’ birthday parties, horse riding and sports in Ballarat. The family then make a road trip to South Australia, featuring city streets in Adelaide, a visit to an amusement park and a wildlife sanctuary, and more horse riding.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 kids’ athletics day
00:01:16:00 girl dismounting a horse from the back of the saddle
00:02:05:00 horse-riding at an equestrian club
00:07:13:00 a group of kids having fun on a trampoline
00:07:30:00 riding a horse in the backyard
00:08:05:00 kids seated around a table eating cake
00:08:50:00 blowing out the candles on the cake
00:10:24:00 playing musical chairs
00:12:01:00 kids’ footy (AFL football) match
00:14:01:00 a nun cheering from the sidelines
00:16:05:00 parents watching from the sidelines
00:18:31:00 man riding a horse down a suburban street
00:20:45:00 on a road trip, at the border of South Australia
00:21:59:00 fish and chips on the bonnet of the car
00:23:25:00 busy Adelaide street with Colonial Mutual Life Assurance Society building in the background
00:24:09:00 in a department store
00:24:53:00 the kids on a Ferris Wheel and other carnival rides
00:25:50:00 trained seals doing tricks
00:28:00:00 dolphins jumping through rings
00:29:42:00 group family shot at a wildlife sanctuary
00:30:56:00 kids patting a kangaroo
00:32:00:00 kids walking down the steps of an ANSETT plane
00:33:12:00 one of the kids on a tire swing
00:34:18:00 cowboy on a horse
00:34:52:00 paddling around in kayaks on a lake
00:36:23:00 on a boat cruising down the river
00:37:08:00 old steam trains in a yard
00:37:15:00 city streets including trams
00:37:58:00 boys running down train tracks
00:39:01:00 arriving home and pulling suitcases out of the boot of the car

results.title: Blind grace
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: New York City — a huge, slow pulse of light steaming through daytime and night time. A study of the soul of the city, its radiance, its isolates and its irates — the special souls who are lost to the vision of the workaday world but scorched into the vision of Cohen’s video world. A world of blindness, grace and vision. A world made more sacred by noise — the special noise composed in response to the city’s scorching radiance, another kind of soul music.

results.title: Fred's Films. Our Family [excerpt]
results.brief_description: Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker, follows his family’s trip into the City of Melbourne. Starting out at St. Kilda Road, they go on into town to sample coffee and sandwiches al fresco-style before journeying on to an exciting game of Australian Rules football at the MCG (Geelong vs. Hawthorn Grand Final 1963). The family meanders around the fountain at the Southern Cross hotel and ventures to Cook’s Cottage in the picturesque Fitzroy Gardens. They finish up the relaxing day with a cold beverage in the beer garden of the Chevron Hotel.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents some cinema promotional footage shot at the Ballarat drive-in and a local airstrip along with some shots from a VFL football match.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:14:00 close-up shot of car radio being adjusted for drive-in sound
00:06:15:00 VFL football match at Waverley park including junior footy at half-time
00:08:46:00 airplane taking off with “Superman is coming for xmas” banner behind it

results.title: [Melbourne buildings]
results.brief_description: A compilation of short segments highlighting various Melbourne buildings. ‘Elizabeth Tower Motel’ showcasing the cantilever staircase; construction of the new ‘Allan’s Music’ building; a modern office building; Parliament House; St Vincent’s Hospital; demolition of a building on an unidentified site; footage of the intersection of Flinders and Swanston streets taken from Southbank showing the Federation Square site and surrounds before the Gas and Fuel towers were constructed and demolished; ornamental gates near St Paul’s Cathedral; ANZ Bank.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film shows scenes of travelling around the Victorian countryside on motorcycles (motorbikes).

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 motorcycles being filmed from a vehicle travelling alongside
00:00:20:00 motorcycle rider with passenger wearing a beret
00:00:40:00 motorcycle riders gather for the camera at the Atlantic Garage in Ballarat
00:01:17:00 riding the motorcycles down a dusty road

group.title: [John Anderson Home Movie Collection]
group.material_description: 7x 16mm film assorted newsreels and home movie. Can of 9.5mm assorted smaller reels. Focus on Ballarat. Family collection by filmmaker John (Jack) Anderson (dec.)

results.title: [Remix: Hats]
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to hats and how we wear them. A remix of home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection featuring styles, shapes and fabrics of hats. Whether at the beach, riding a horse, driving a racing car or going for a swim, a fashionable head-covering is a must. Australian fashion’s best styles of hats for men, women and children from the 1930s to the 1980s are shown.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Tony Agapitos, Karen Wootton, The Gadsden Family, Elenor Peach, Karen Corry, Jenny & Owen Peake, Gil Brealey & Paul Olson and John Richardson.
